The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 is cited in Section 1. Section 2 outlines the specifications of the coin. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins issued under this Act shall be a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden. On each coin, there. The coins issued under this Act shall feature a design of a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden, along with inscriptions of the coin's value, the year 1995, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "United States of America". The coins issued under this Act shall be a designation of the value of the coin, an inscription of the year '1995', and inscriptions of the words 'Liberty', 'In God We Trust', 'United States of America', and 'E Pluribus Unum'. Legal tender. The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. Selection of design. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Quality of coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Mint Facility - No more than 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins minted under this Act. Period of Issuance - The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act during the period beginning on January 1, 1995, and ending on. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act during the period beginning on January 1, 1995, and ending on December 31, 1995. -S-E-C-. -6-. -S-A-L-E -O-F -C-O-I-N-S-. The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the sum of the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in subsection (d) with respect to such coins, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins (including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, overhead expenses, marketing, and shipping). Bulk sales - The Secretary shall. The Secretary shall make bulk sales available at a reasonable discount and accept prepaid orders for the authorized coins prior to issuance. Bulk sales are available at a reasonable discount and prepaid orders are accepted for authorized coins before issuance. Sales include a surcharge of $10 per coin. General waiver of procurement regulations. No provision of law governing procurement or public contracts applies to the procurement of goods or services necessary for carrying out the provisions of this Act. Nothing in this section relieves any person entering into a contract under this Act from complying with any law relating to equal employment opportunity. Distribution of surcharges. Distribution of surcharges received by the Secretary from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid by the Secretary to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. Audits are also required. The Comptroller General has the right to examine the books, records, documents, and data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to expenditures. The Act is titled the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" and specifies coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 silver coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The design of the coins includes a rose and the United States Botanic Garden facade, along with inscriptions of the coin's value and the year "1995". The coins issued under this Act shall feature a rose and the United States Botanic Garden facade, with inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "1995", and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act in 1995 feature inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins are legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee for the coins minted under this Act. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single US Mint facility from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be available at a discount, prepaid orders will be accepted, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge. The Secretary will offer bulk sales at a discount and accept prepaid orders for coins authorized under this Act. All sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS.

No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws.

SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales under this Act go to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales under this Act are promptly paid to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden.

SEC. 9. AUDITS.

The Comptroller General of the United States can examine the National Fund's books and records related to the expenditures from section 8.
